description: A rich, creamy, and uniquely flavored dish made by blending thick, fermented sour milk with a smooth, savory groundnut paste. The tangy, sharp notes of the sour milk are beautifully balanced by the nutty, earthy richness of the groundnuts, creating a thick, protein-packed sauce or paste that is both refreshing and deeply satisfying. It can be served as a thick drink, a dip, or a sauce.

cultural_significance.cultural_notes: This combination is a powerhouse of nutrition, commonly prepared in households that have easy access to both milk from their cattle and home-grown groundnuts. It is often given to children and the elderly for its high protein and fat content. It represents the pastoralist culture of Western Uganda, combining two of their most important food resources into one simple, yet profoundly nourishing, dish. It's a quick energy booster for herders.

ingredients.name: Thick Fermented Sour Milk (Bongo)
ingredients.notes: Should be thick and tangy. Well-fermented Bongo or plain, thick, unsweetened yogurt can be used.

ingredients.name: Pure Groundnut Paste (Peanut Butter)
ingredients.notes: Unsweetened and unsalted is best for a traditional taste.

ingredients.name: Honey or Sugar (optional)
ingredients.notes: A tiny amount can be added to balance the tanginess, especially for children.

steps.instruction: Scoop the thick sour milk (Bongo) into a mixing bowl.
Add the groundnut paste to the bowl. If the paste is very thick, you can warm it slightly to make it easier to mix.
Using a whisk or a strong wooden spoon, vigorously mix the two ingredients together until they are completely smooth, well-incorporated, and no streaks of groundnut paste remain.
Taste the mixture. Add a pinch of salt and/or a teaspoon of honey/sugar if desired, and mix thoroughly again.
The consistency should be thick and creamy, like a smoothie or a runny pudding. If it is too thick for your liking, you can thin it with a very small amount of fresh milk or water.
Serve immediately. The mixture can be drunk, eaten with a spoon, or used as a dip.

serving_suggestions: Served as a thick, cold drink in a cup or calabash. It can also be eaten with a spoon as a light meal or snack. Traditionally, it is consumed on its own, but it can also be used as a dip for roasted sweet potatoes or spread on millet bread (Kalo).
